content: The "Drinking Water Protection Act" includes an amendment to the Safe Drinking Water Act, adding a new section for assessing and managing risks associated with algal toxins in public water systems. The Administrator is required to develop a strategic plan within 90 days to evaluate health risks and establish a comprehensive list. The "Drinking Water Protection Act" mandates the Administrator to create a list of algal toxins affecting human health in public water systems and assess their adverse effects. This includes determining factors leading to toxin production and deciding on issuing health advisories for these toxins in drinking water. The "Drinking Water Protection Act" requires the Administrator to establish guidance on quantifying algal toxins in public water systems, recommend treatment options to mitigate health effects, and provide technical assistance to affected States and water systems. The Administrator will update and submit a strategic plan to Congress for managing risks associated with algal toxins. They will also identify gaps in understanding algal toxins and consult with other Federal agencies as needed. The Administrator will consult with various entities including Federal agencies, States, public water system operators, multinational agencies, foreign governments, research institutions, and companies providing drinking water treatment options to gather and publish information on cyanobacteria, algal toxins, and harmful algal blooms. This will be done in accordance with scientific requirements. The Comptroller General of the United States will prepare and submit a report to Congress within 90 days of the enactment of the Act. The report will include an inventory of funds expended by the United States from 2010 to 2014 to examine toxin-producing cyanobacteria and algae, along with details on the purpose, authorization, and recipient of the funds. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The report will include an inventory of funds spent by the US from 2010 to 2014 on toxin-producing cyanobacteria and algae, along with recommendations to reduce duplication and improve interagency coordination of such expenditures.
